headline.main: SEEKING CLUES TO DISEASE IN THE DETAILS OF DAILY LIFE

docs.lead_paragraph: Starting Wednesday, some 100,000 volunteers in 50 states and Puerto Rico will circulate health questionnaires to their friends, neighbors and relatives, thus launching the American Cancer Society's ''Cancer Prevention Study II.'' It is the first time since 1959 that the Cancer Society has sponsored an epidemiological study of such magnitude and at such expense. The project is expected to cost between $10 million and $12 million. The object is to keep tabs on 1.2 million Americans for the next few years and so discern the factors in their lives that seem linked, or not linked, to the incidence of cancer. The survey, for example, will touch on issues of diet, cigarette use and exposure to known carcinogens in the environment and workplace.
